posts.title: 10 Ways to Make the Most of the Library (And Your Library Card) During Kids' Winter Break
posts.text: Get up to speed below with lots of ideas for winter break fun!

posts.title: Festive Holiday Reads for Kids and Teens
posts.text: Take a break from the swirl of holiday activities to share a book with a young person in your life or, for older kids and teens, recommend a festive read to get them into the spirit of the season.

posts.title: Nine New Holiday Reads to Bring Good Cheer
posts.text: These holiday books are all newly published and will help get you in the most festive of moods before the holidays or extend the cozy feelings into the new year. We hope you can read one nestled all snug in your bed!

posts.title: End of Year Literary Quiz: 2021 Edition
posts.text: From book awards to publishing news and more, how well did you pay attention to the literary news this year?

posts.title: One for Each Night: Books for Every Age To Celebrate Hanukkah
posts.text: These books—an assortment for all ages—will help put you in a celebratory mood as you light your candles, sing songs, spin dreidels, open gifts, and gather around the table with loved ones.

posts.title: Notable Book Adaptations Out Now Or Coming Soon
posts.text: The trend of adapting books into film and television shows is at full throttle. Here are a list of adaptations that are out now or will be available soon. They include literary fiction, sci-fi and fantasy bestsellers, a children's classic, and even a few works of nonfiction.

posts.title: Nine New Cozy Mysteries to Read Under the Covers
posts.text: Set the kettle, turn off your phone, and cozy up with one of these new reads.

posts.title: E-Magazines Kids & Teens Can Enjoy At Home
posts.text: Hobbies, sports, fashion, history, news, animals, gaming—there's something for everyone from preschoolers to older teens.

posts.title: Last-Minute Literary Halloween Costume Inspiration from NYPL's Digital Collections
posts.text: Jack London, Jane Austen, the Tin Man, and more ideas for down-to-the-wire literary costumes.

posts.title: Enter the Duniverse at the Library
posts.text: Whether you've just seen the movie and want to immersing yourself in the world of Dune, or you want to initiate yourself with the book (or books) before you see it, the Library can hook you up.

posts.title: Nine New Crafting Books To Curl Up With
posts.text: Fall is the perfect time to get your feet wet learning a new craft or getting back into the swing of an old hobby.

posts.title: Oi! Reading Recommendations for Ted Lasso & the AFC Richmond Crew
posts.text: Ted and friends will have more time on their hands in the off season and, let's face it, many of them could really use it to get their mental houses in order. These books may hold the heaping spoonfuls of truth soup they need to work on themselves and come back strong next season.

posts.title: Dive Into the 2021 National Book Awards Finalists
posts.text: There are many names among these outstanding authors you may recognize from previous award lists, but also newer writers including several with a debut title.

posts.title: What To Read While You Wait for Your Sally Rooney Hold
posts.text: While Rooney's literary sensibility and style are all her own, these books share complex, emotionally rich characters that we think you'll love.

posts.title: Stirring Survival Tales for Fans of Squid Game
posts.text: 'Squid Game's' central themes of survival and morality are familiar ones in literature, and while the show is certainly its own unique (and intense!) experience, these books offer some of the same dark thrills.

posts.title: Nine New Sci-Fi & Fantasy Reads to Take You to Other Worlds
posts.text: These titles will take you off the planet, into an alternate or future version of Earth, or begin in a familiar reality and end up somewhere far, far different.

posts.title: Reading the 2021 Emmy Nominations
posts.text: The annual Emmy awards, recognizing excellence in television, take place this Sunday and—not unusually—feature many programs with strong ties to books. Especially if you've run out of things to watch, take a look at some of the nominated shows and the books that inspired them or related reading.

posts.title: Style & Substance: A Fashion Reading List
posts.text: Whether you're drawn to the glamour, the garments, or the dynamic personalities who inhabit this world, these books offer a window into this ultra-creative, yet ultra-competitive industry.

posts.title: Malcolm and Muhammad, Zora and Langston, Adams and Jefferson, and More Stories of Fraught Friendships
posts.text: These books depict high-profile friendships with rifts, ruptures, and, in some cases, implosions.

posts.title: Americans at Work: Images from the Digital Collections
posts.text: Our Digital Collections hold hundreds of photographs of Americans at work. Most are from the first half of the 20th century and represent a wide variety of jobs, some of which no longer exist.

posts.title: Absorbing Fiction Reads for Fans of The Chair
posts.text: As these novels show, the campus setting—a fishbowl of heightened tensions and grievances—is ripe for literary exploration.

posts.title: Nine New Debut Novels That Dazzle
posts.text: These new fiction voices brim with confidence, boldness, and fresh ideas.

posts.title: Anne, Emma, Jo, Lizzy, Jane, Alice: Contemporary Retellings of Classic Novels
posts.text: Enjoy the riffs, reinterpretations, and reimaginings of these contemporary retellings of classic novels including much of Jane Austen's oeuvre, 'Jane Eyre', 'Anne of Green Gables', 'Alice in Wonderland', 'Little Women', and more!

posts.title: Olympians of the Past: Images from NYPL's Digital Collections
posts.text: Most of these athletes competed over a hundred years ago and their achievements in sport and beyond have been largely forgotten. We invite you to view the photos, learn a little of these athletes' stories, and explore more in our online Digital Collections.

posts.title: Explore Books From the 2021 Booker Prize Longlist
posts.text: The longlist for the 2021 Booker Prize, one of literature's most prestigious awards, has just been announced and includes a wide range of exciting fiction from authors around the world.

posts.title: What To Read If You Already Breezed Through All of Virgin River's Season 3
posts.text: Whether you never read the book series, are looking for similar small-town romances, or want an uplifting book about starting over, we've got reading recommendations while you wait for another season of 'Virgin River'.

posts.title: Beach Reads for Every Kind of Mood
posts.text: A good "beach read" can mean something different to everyone: a thrilling mystery, an engrossing novel, a sweet romance, an engrossing nonfiction title, an emotional memoir, and much more. Here's wishing you find the perfect book to suit your mood—some suggestions are below.

posts.title: Hot Town: Photos of Summer in New York City
posts.text: To celebrate summer in the city, we've put together images from NYPL's Digital Collections showing New Yorkers through the decades enjoying all that summer has to offer. We made sure to include quintessential summer spots like Coney Island, Central Park, and the Rockaways. And, of course, Mister Softee.

posts.title: 10 YA Thrillers for Fans of Cruel Summer
posts.text: While you wait for a second season of the thrilling TV drama, we have some suspenseful YA books to suggest that will satisfy a craving for deception, secrecy, and the slow unraveling of the truth.

posts.title: A Summer of Soul Companion Reading List
posts.text: These books make great companion reads for the film if you're inspired to learn more about the musicians who performed at the Harlem Cultural Festival, this era of music and its intersection with activism, and Harlem's cultural importance.

posts.title: Spot On: Cookbooks & Memoirs From Your Top Chef Favorites
posts.text: Whether you love to cook, love to eat, or just can't get enough of your Top Chef favorites, there's a book here that's sure to inspire.

posts.title: Emotionally Gripping Reads for Fans of In Treatment
posts.text: If you enjoy the intensity and blurred boundaries of the therapist-patient dynamic or being a fly on the wall as traumas and anxieties are unwrapped and picked apart, you may enjoy some of the fictional reads below which have psychologists and psychotherapists as the protagonist or that revolve around the experience of therapy.

posts.title: Read These Newly Minted Pulitzer Prize Winners
posts.text: In addition to multiple prizes for journalism, the awards each year recognize outstanding books in the categories of fiction, biography, poetry, history, and general nonfiction. The weekend is beginning—get started on one of these remarkable books!

posts.title: Warm Up for the Westminster Show with These Past Dog Champions
posts.text: In honor of the show, we're highlighting some of the dogs in the "Best Dogs of Their Breed" cigarette card collection which showcases 50 past champions of dog shows around the country and world.

posts.title: Moody Crime Reads for Fans of Mare of Easttown
posts.text: If the show's twist-filled finale left you wanting more, we have book suggestions that may tick some of the same boxes.

posts.title: Nine New Thrillers You Won't Be Able To Put Down
posts.text: Twists and turns, secrets and lies, dark pasts and precarious presents, a good thriller will keep you guessing and on the edge of your seat until the very end.

posts.title: A Taste of Historic Mother's Day Menus
posts.text: Looking at old menus is like boarding a time machine to get a glimpse into a world that no longer exists.

posts.title: Cicada Fever is Here!
posts.text: Much like infrequent astrological events, the arrival of the cicadas is considered by many to be one of Earth's extraordinary natural occurrences and witnessing it is an exciting few-times-in-a-lifetime event. For cicada enthusiasts, we've gathered together some images from our Digital Collections for you to view. Enjoy!

posts.title: Quiz: Is It a Racehorse...Or a Novel?
posts.text: Racehorse names are often fanciful, weird, and—we couldn't help but notice—sometimes have a poetic or literary quality. See if you can guess which is which.

posts.title: Read the Women's Prize for Fiction Shortlist
posts.text: The purpose of the prize is to "champion women writers on a global stage" and the winning books over the years are an exciting collection of compelling fiction. This would be quite the summer reading list!

posts.title: Exciting Book Adaptations to Watch Out For
posts.text: Adapting books into films and tv series is nothing new and it seems, more and more, that the literary world is fueling Hollywood. What is new is that the books being adapted increasingly reflect more diversity in genre and creators.

posts.title: Check Out These 'Wildly Original' Titles Selected for the International Booker Prize Shortlist
posts.text: If you enjoy global literature, check out the translated works that just made the shortlist for the 2021 Booker International Prize.

posts.title: Nine New Cookbooks to Whet Your Appetite
posts.text: Try a new cookbook to discover new flavors, techniques and recipes—these below are brand new and showcase an exciting array of cuisines from amazing chefs around the world.

posts.title: Urgent, Hopeful Reads for Earth Day
posts.text: There's no better day than Earth Day to decide to learn more about the impact we have on the environment and the work being done by scientists and activists to ensure our planet's future.

posts.title: 10 Reads for Fans of Made for Love
posts.text: A penny for your thoughts? No matter. An implanted brain chip creates a mind-meld between you and your partner. Dark, hilarious, and perceptive, 'Made for Love' didn't lose its weirdness as the novel was adapted into a tv series for HBO. If the show and book are your cup of tea, we have suggestions for books with similar themes and vibes.

posts.title: Nine New Memoirs to Step Into
posts.text: A chef, an activist, an actress, a psychologist, a scrap metal collector, and more—here are nine new memoirs, all published in the past few months, ready for you to get lost in.

posts.title: The Audie Award Winners: Discover Your Next Great Listen
posts.text: Whether you love to listen to books while you walk or run, while doing the dishes or other chores, or during your commute (if your commute is farther than from the kitchen to your dining room table or home office these days), these award winners are a great place to discover some excellent listens.

posts.title: Quiz: How Well Do You Know Your Book Adaptations?
posts.text: Some of the biggest successes on the big and small screen over the past few decades started their creative life as books—do you know which ones?

posts.title: Would You Rather: Grammar Edition
posts.text: In honor of National Grammar Day, we've put together some fun "would you rather" conundrums to ponder.

posts.title: A Judas and the Black Messiah Reading List
posts.text: If you were captivated by the movie and want to keep learning about these people, this era, and the Black Panthers, we have some suggestions to go deeper into the history.

posts.title: Reading the 2021 Golden Globes Nominations
posts.text: Whether or not you pay much attention to Hollywood awards, you many enjoy reading some of the works that these films and television series were adapted from either as companions to a show or film you've enjoyed or on their own worthy merits.

posts.title: 2021 Winners: Newbery, Caldecott, King, Printz & More Awards from the American Library Association
posts.text: For librarians who love and promote books for children and young adults, the Youth Media Awards are as good as it gets. See if your favorite took home a prize this year!

posts.title: A Reading List for Bookstore Lovers
posts.text: Authors have an obvious connection to bookstores so it's no surprise that booksellers and bookstores have provided fodder for some terrific reads. Below you'll find both fiction and nonfiction titles that will take you inside these venerated spaces and into the world of books and those who love them.

posts.title: Listen: Susan Orlean on Writing The Orchid Thief
posts.text: We're delighted that the second episode of the new podcast Spark & Fire featuring author Susan Orlean sharing how her book The Orchid Thief came to be, is dedicated to the New York Public Library for "creating a love for reading and supporting great writers."

posts.title: Get Inspired by These Books About Bold One-Year Life Experiments
posts.text: From a 'Year of Less' to a 'Year of Yes,' these authors went way beyond making small resolutions or minor modifications to their lives.

posts.title: A Look Back: Our End of Year Literary Quiz
posts.text: How closely did you follow along with literary news this year?

posts.title: Already Dashed Through Season One of Dash & Lily? Readalikes to Recreate the Mood
posts.text: Did you already get a jump-start on the holidays by watching all eight episodes of the Christmas-themed Netflix series Dash & Lily? If you did and were charmed, but also feel a little glum that the series is over so soon, we have some YA books in mind that can help recreate the magic.

posts.title: Feast Your Eyes on These Cooking Magazines (Accessible From Home)
posts.text: Thanksgiving may be downsized this year for many people, but that doesn't mean you have to give up on a delectable meal. If you relish trying out new recipes and making the day special, there are plenty of food and cooking magazines you can pore over from home with your library card.

posts.title: Get Excited for Prime Day!
posts.text: Did you wake up this morning with a jittery, excited, anything-can-happen feeling? We did, too! And why not, it's one of the most anticipated days of the year—Prime Day.

posts.title: Cookbooks by The Great British Baking Show Contestants & Hosts
posts.text: On your marks, get set, read! (Then bake!)

posts.title: Books to Celebrate the Life & Legacy of Ruth Bader Ginsburg
posts.text: A feminist icon to generations of women and girls and, in her later years, an unexpected pop culture hero, Ginsburg's life and career are inspiring to many.

posts.title: Get Excited for the Tour de France with These Reads
posts.text: The pandemic has pushed the Tour to late summer so there's still time to familiarize yourself with it if you've been missing sports.

posts.title: Reading the 2020 Emmy Nominations
posts.text: The nominations announced today were a reminder of the dark dramas and clever comedies that formerly occupied our evenings, many of which we hope to see again in future seasons.

posts.title: The Baby-Sitters Club Books & Other Nostalgic Middle Grade Reads
posts.text: If you're looking for some light summer reading, a walk down this reading memory lane is only a few clicks away with your library card.

posts.title: E-Books to Get Your Kids Cooking This Summer
posts.text: Whether you love to cook or approach it from a more utilitarian perspective, it's a wonderful skill (and art) to share with and pass on to a child.

posts.title: Put on a Corsage and Check Out a Prom-Themed Book
posts.text: From the horror classic 'Carrie' to contemporary romance 'Deacon Locke Went to Prom', there's a prom book for whatever mood you're in.

posts.title: Think You Know Nancy Drew? Prove It With Our Quiz
posts.text: Whether you're a completist or have just dabbled in a few books, we're betting that some knowledge of Nancy and her capers has seeped into your consciousness.

posts.title: Possibly Dubious Spring Cleaning Advice from Vintage Cigarette Cards
posts.text: Oh, what you can do with a potato!

posts.title: The Greatest Commencement Speeches, in Book Form
posts.text: Perhaps the extra boost of inspiration grads need as they transition to a new phase of life with more uncertainty than ever.

posts.title: Much Ado About Shakespeare: Modern Adaptations & Retellings
posts.text: These books take the central themes that Shakespeare explored and gives them new settings, characters and interpretations.

posts.title: E-Books for Kids to Learn Coding at Home
posts.text: It's a parent-kid win-win.

posts.title: Vintage Postcards to Celebrate Easter
posts.text: Who can ever get enough of bunnies playing baseball?

posts.title: Expand Your Reading Horizons with a Selection from the International Booker Prize Shortlist
posts.text: The prize honors authors and translators equally.

posts.title: Get Spirited Away by Books About Magic & Magicians
posts.text: “Look at this life—all mystery and magic.” —Harry Houdini

posts.title: Hang in There, Parents: Craft, Art & Activity E-Books to Help Keep Your Kids Busy
posts.text: If you're looking for ideas of things to make and do, the Library has plenty of books to get you started.

posts.title: NYPL Connect: Keep in Touch with Our Digital Resources
posts.text: Sign up for the NYPL Connect e-newsletter to stay up-to-date with Library resources available during our temporary closure.

posts.title: Help Fellow New Yorkers Out by "Returning" Digital Materials As Soon As You're Done
posts.text: The sooner you return your digital materials, the sooner someone else can use them.

posts.title: #LiteraryMarchMadness 2020: Book Series Edition
posts.text: Who will prevail???

posts.title: A Bit O' Blarney: Vintage St. Patrick's Day Postcards
posts.text: "The day that brings a smile To every son and daughter Of dear old Erin's Isle"

posts.title: Everything You Always Wanted to Know About Putting a Book on Hold (But Were Afraid to Ask)
posts.text: Placing a hold is only three simple steps: search, click, pick it up!

posts.title: A Book List of Women Standing Up Around the World
posts.text:
Women are raising their voices and organizing for change across the globe.

Books to Celebrate

posts.title: Great Books About Sleep That Are Worth Losing Sleep Over
posts.text: Fiction, non-fiction and memoirs by epically bad sleepers.

posts.title: Women's History Month Reads: "Ordinary" Women Who Made Extraordinary Contributions
posts.text: We may not know their names, but we can learn their stories and be inspired by their resolve, their sacrifices and their courage.

posts.title: Celebrate Women's History Events With Us At the Library
posts.text: Movie screenings, author talks, poetry readings, a Women's Jazz Festival, a Jeopardy competition and much more.

posts.title: To Have & To Hold: Download and Print Our 125 Books We Love List
posts.text: Tally up the ones you've read and circle what's next, bring copies to your book club group,  mail one to a friend...

posts.title: In a Mardi Gras Mood? Check Out These Mysteries Set in the Big Easy
posts.text: If you're looking for a dose of New Orleans, perhaps no other genre captures its distinctive culture like mysteries.

posts.title: Uplifting Comfort Reads for Days When You Just Can't
posts.text: They're as good as a warm bowl of soup.

posts.title: Was it Love at First Line? Match the Opening Sentence to the Book
posts.text: You only have one chance to make a first impression.

posts.title: See It, Be It: Inspiring Picture Books about Women Scientists
posts.text: These girls followed their dreams, worked hard and made their mark in the world.

posts.title: Forgotten History: Books to Honor Women's Contributions to Science
posts.text: Meet these pioneering women from past and present.

posts.title: Get Excited to #LoveReading for Our 125th Anniversary
posts.text: Our Valentine's gift to you this year is 125 Books We Love

posts.title: Remembering Mary Higgins Clark
posts.text: Saying goodbye to the "Queen of Suspense"

posts.title: Celebrate Black History Month with Books for Young Readers
posts.text: From picture books for tots to books for teens.

posts.title: Celebrate Black History Month 2020 at the Library!
posts.text: Upcoming events include book discussions, films, genealogy research, author talks and much, much more.

posts.title: 20 Great Football Reads Even Non-Fans Will Love
posts.text: You don't need to know a blitz from a bump-and-run to enjoy these books.

posts.title: 2020 Winners: Newbery, Caldecott, King, Printz & More Awards from the American Library Association
posts.text: And the award goes to...

posts.title: Celebrate the 7th Annual #LibraryShelfie Day with Us!
posts.text: "We're ready for our close-up!" say library shelves all over the world today.

posts.title: Can You Ace Our Synonym Quiz?
posts.text: We're celebrating National Thesaurus Day with a test of your synonym skills...

posts.title: Ben Franklin: The Ultimate Bibliophile
posts.text: Benjamin Franklin's contributions to science, politics, and diplomacy are immense, but his passion for and support of books and libraries is what has endeared him to us most here at the Library.

posts.title: Some of Your Favorite Books are Hitting the Small Screen
posts.text: We're living in an age of great television. Is it a coincidence that so many hit shows are based on hit books? Maybe, maybe not. A slew of new shows are hitting the waves which had their start as books and we can't wait to watch and read them all.

posts.title: These 2020 Oscar Contenders Started as Books
posts.text: Nominations for the 2020 Oscars awards have been announced. Many of the films are adapted from or draw their inspiration from a reliable and oft-visited well—books! Whether you like to compare the film to the book or eschew the film altogether and go straight to the source, there are some great reads here both fiction and non-fiction.

posts.title: Remember Mail? Old Postcards to Celebrate a New Year
posts.text: If you miss the days when your mailbox was fuller than your inbox, take a look through some old New Year's postcards from the NYPL Digital Collections.

posts.title: From Books to the Big Screen: January 2020
posts.text: Whether you just can't bear to see a movie before you've had a chance to read the book or seeing the movie inspires you to explore the original source material, we've put together a list of about-to-be-released movies and their book counterparts which, of course, you can check out from the library.

posts.title: These Are the 'Star Wars' Books You've Been Looking For
posts.text: Are you in the Star Wars zone? After you see the new movie, further your adventures in this universe through audio books, graphic novels, children's books, non-fiction and more.
